utterances: Michelle, thanks very much for the call.
And let's see if we can get one last caller in.
This is Marie.
Marie with us from Cedar Rapids in Iowa.
Yes.
Go ahead, please.

Well, I was going to say that just that I think that the game shows going more towards the entertainment value rather than the cerebral is a symptom of a broader move in society away from a respect for the liberal education toward the focusing of specialized skills.
Does that make sense or do you need me to clarify that?
No, I think that makes sense.
Does it make sense to you, Ken Jennings?
Yeah.
I argue very strongly for that in ""Brainiac."" That, you know, part of the reason trivia is important is because - you don't have to call it trivia, it's just cultural literacy.
It used to be the stuff that we all knew before our career and educational niches isolated us in this very specialized knowledge.
You know, it was conversation starters and it was the thing that united us as a culture.

And I think we are losing that and that's reason game shows have to ask about celebrity baby names and Vanity fashion imprints, because there's so much less knowledge that we all share from that liberal education.
Paul?
That's true.

And I would also say that trivia gets a bad rap, because there is no fact that isn't connected to another fact and can lead you on to a much broader search that's much more intellectually stimulating.
So don't dismiss it as random facts.
Those facts are part of a much larger whole.
Marie, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
And Paul Farhi, thank you for joining us today.
Thank you, Neal.
Paul Farhi's a media reporter for the Washington Post.

He wrote the story ""Easy Does It: With New Quiz Shows, Boob Tube Earns Its Name."" And we need to thank Ken Jennings as well, not just the 74-time ""Jeopardy"" winner, but last year as the celebrity speaker at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament entered the contest and won the rookie class.
Ken, are you going back to Stamford to defend your title?
I will not be able to defend my title this year, Neal.
But if you go, say hi to everybody for me.
I had a blast.
I'll be going to Stamford on Saturday and I'll say hi to everybody for you.
I don't compete.
I just do the play-by-play of the finals.
But Ken Jennings, thanks very much for being with us today.
My pleasure as always.
Ken Jennings also the author of ""Brainiac."" He joins us today from KXOT, our member station in Seattle, Washington.
When we come back from a short break, why would anyone go to every shop at the Mall of America and spend $15,000 along the way?
We'll find out in a few minutes.
I'm Ed Gordon and this is NEWS AND NOTES.
I'm Neal Conan.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And before the break, a quick aside on international relations and summits - China and the U.S.
regularly spar over trade and foreign policy and now supercomputers.
The U.S.
Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory this past week unveiled the aptly named Summit.
Oak Ridge says it's the world's most powerful and smartest scientific supercomputer, taking the top spot from China.
The last time a U.S.
supercomputer held the crown was in 2012.
And get this - Summit has a peak performance of two hundred thousand trillion calculations per second or 200 petaflops - peta what?
OK.
Here's an easier way to think about it.
If every person on Earth completed one calculation per second, it would take the world population 305 days to do what Summit can do in one second.
Whoa.
But maybe the United States shouldn't gloat too much about having this computer.

China might not have the speediest supercomputer in the world any longer, but according to an industry ranking of the 500 fastest supercomputers in the world, China has the world's most supercomputers overall, with the U.S.
in second place.
The White House is hosting a social media summit today.
President Trump is known for his passionate use of social media, specifically Twitter, which he often deploys to rally his base.
The guest list at the event will feature some members of Congress and several of his social media fans.
It's a who's who of conservative personalities, some associated with the ""alt-right."" Big tech giants like Twitter and Facebook have not been invited.
NPR's Jasmine Garsd has the story.
When he got the email invitation to the White House, Twitter personality Carpe Donktum thought it might be a spam.
When I first got it, I was like, well, this seems kind of official, but I'm not sure that it is.
Carpe Donktum requested that we withhold his real name.
He says he fears retaliation against his family.
So how does a stay-at-home dad in Kansas whose real name is not public get invited to the White House?
Because on Twitter, he's a celebrity with over 100,000 followers.
Carpe Donktum, by the way, roughly comes from Latin.
It's a parody meaning seize the donkey, referring to Democrats.

He's a prolific creator of pro-Trump images and videos, which he tweets out, like this one, footage of the State of the Union featuring clearly unhappy Democrats in the audience with the band R.E.M.'s ""Everybody Hurts"" playing over it.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Singing) Don't let yourself go...
That America will never be a socialist country.
(Singing) ...'Cause everybody cries.
It was retweeted by the president, who has since shared several other of Carpe Donktum's spoofs.
Later today, Carpe Donktum will be attending a social media summit organized by the White House.
Twitter is President Trump's preferred way of getting his message out.
And while the White House has been mum about the guest list, some people have tweeted out their invitations.
Many of them are part of the Trump Twitterverse, conservative social media personalities who orbit around Trump's bright Twitter star.
But Trump has attacked those same social media platforms.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
You look at Google, Facebook, Twitter and other social media giants.
And I've made it clear that we as a country cannot tolerate political censorship, blacklisting and rigged search results.
Both Google and Facebook have denied that they censor the right.
A lot of people believe that's just not true.
Conservative talk show host Bill Mitchell, who's also going to the summit, blames Twitter's algorithm for some of his followers not being able to see his tweets.
He hopes at the summit they talk about how social media has become the modern public square.
And if you become the public square, you really need to offer First Amendment protections to people where everybody can have free and open speech.
Let's have the open debate, and may the best man win.
Angelo Carusone, from the liberal nonprofit Media Matters, believes in free speech.
But he says some of the guests at the summit alarm him.
You know, there's a couple establishment players there.
But for the most part, they're far-right figures, they're extremists and a lot of people with ties to white nationalism.

Mitchell and Carpe Donktum disavowed racism to NPR, but Media Matters also points to other guests, like Charlie Kirk from Turning Point USA, an organization that has been accused of racist viewpoints.
Here's Carusone again.
When you start to bring in all these individuals that are connected to or have relationships to these communities, what they do is they go back and they validate - oh, yeah, I met with the president.
I was at the White House.
You know, we're a part of this.
The normalization of this is the part that concerns me.
And as the president rallies his base ahead of the 2020 elections, Carusone wonders about the effect of elevating these voices on the right.
Jasmine Garsd, NPR News, New York.
From NPR News, it's Day to Day.

Treasury busy again today in the U.S.
financial system.
